articles.headline: Well-Oiled Security Apparatus in China Stifles Calls for Change
articles.snippet: The government is relying on repression and incentives to prevent a challenge similar to those in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The government is relying on repression and incentives to prevent a challenge similar to those in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  The call to action shot across mobile phones and Internet chat sites, urging people to converge on 13 Chinese cities to demand an end to corruption, inflation and the strictures of authoritarian rule. “The Chinese people do not have the patience to wait any longer,” said one message.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: In Shadow of 1995, G.O.P. Freshmen Stand Firm
articles.snippet: The new class of Republicans in Congress want to avoid a shutdown but still redefine the federal government’s role.
articles.abstract: The new class of Republicans in Congress want to avoid a shutdown but still redefine the federal government’s role.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The specter of the 1995 government shutdown hangs over Capitol Hill, a memory many hoped to leave behind, along with beepers and episodes of “Baywatch Nights.”

articles.headline: Clothes Makers Join to Set ‘Green Score’
articles.snippet: A coalition of retailers and clothing makers, including Wal-Mart, is planning to issue sustainability scores that the industry, and eventually shoppers, will use.
articles.abstract: A coalition of retailers and clothing makers, including Wal-Mart, is planning to issue sustainability scores that the industry, and eventually shoppers, will use.
articles.lead_paragraph: With just a few clicks on Google Maps, anyone can call up a satellite image of blue dye and other chemicals washing downriver from textile mills in Xintang, China  the world capital of blue jeans production.

articles.headline: Radical Cleric Demands Ouster of Yemen Leader
articles.snippet: A cleric accused of having links to Al Qaeda joined protesters calling for replacing the government with an Islamic state.
articles.abstract: A cleric accused of having links to Al Qaeda joined protesters calling for replacing the government with an Islamic state.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen  Yemen’s president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, maintained a tenuous hold on power on Tuesday, blaming the United States and Israel for protests across the Arab world, while a prominent radical cleric joined the growing crowds demanding his ouster and called for an Islamic state.
articles.byline: By Laura Kasinof and Scott Shane
